title: Woodworking — Hammering Nails into Soft Wood
description: Introduction to woodworking. The child learns to hold a hammer, position a nail, and drive it into a piece of soft wood (balsa or pine). This builds hand strength, coordination, and confidence with real tools.
instructions:
1. 'Today we use a real hammer and real nails! Woodworking is an important skill.'
2. Safety rules: 'Hold the hammer near the end of the handle. Keep your other hand clear of the nail once you start hammering. Always hammer on the work surface.'
3. Demonstrate: hold the nail near the top, tap it gently to set it in the wood.
4. Once the nail stands on its own, move fingers away. Hammer with firm, controlled taps.
5. 'Your turn! Set the nail first with light taps. Then hammer it in.'
6. Practice driving 4-5 nails into the wood block.
7. Optional: hammer nails in a pattern (straight line, circle, letter).
materials_needed: Soft wood block (balsa, pine, or cork)

slides.heading: Woodworking
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn about woodworking today, which is like being a super builder! We're going to learn how to hammer nails, just like the people who build houses and fun treehouses!

slides.setup_instructions: Clamp the wood block to a sturdy table. Put on safety goggles. Lay out hammer and nails. Draw dots on the wood where nails should go.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need for our building adventure! We have a little hammer, some nails with big tops, and a soft piece of wood that's easy to hammer into. We also need special glasses to keep our eyes safe, and we'll need a grown-up to help clamp the wood down so it doesn't wiggle.

slides.text: 'Today you learn to use a REAL hammer! Woodworkers build furniture, houses, and all sorts of things. First, safety: put on your goggles.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today we get to use a REAL hammer, how exciting! It's like a special tool that builders use to put things together. First, we need to put on our safety glasses to protect our eyes, just like superheroes wear masks!

slides.text: 'Hold the hammer near the END of the handle — that gives you more power. Hold the nail near the TOP with your other hand. Tap GENTLY to set it in the wood.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's learn how to hold the hammer and the nail. Hold the hammer down near the bottom of the stick, like this! Then, put the nail near the top with your other hand, and give it a little tap, tap, tap to make it stand up by itself.

slides.text: Demonstrate: set the nail with 2-3 gentle taps until it stands on its own. 'Now move your fingers AWAY. Hammer with firm, steady taps until the nail is in the wood.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When the nail can stand up all by itself, it's time to move your fingers far away so they are safe! Then, we can give the nail some stronger taps, tap, tap, tap, to push it all the way into the wood.

slides.text: 'Your turn! Pick a spot with a dot. Hold the nail, tap to set it, move your fingers, and hammer it in. Take your time — accuracy matters more than speed.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the builder! Find a little dot on the wood, put the nail there, and give it a gentle tap to make it stand up. Then, move your fingers away and give it some good taps to hammer it in all the way.

slides.prompt: Hammer 4-5 nails into the wood block. Try to follow the dots. Can you make a straight line of nails? A letter? A shape?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's practice hammering in some nails! We can try to make them go in a straight line, or maybe even draw a shape with them. Take your time and make each nail go in nice and straight.

slides.text: Put the hammer back in its place. Remove goggles. 'You used a real tool like a real builder! What would you like to build someday?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child safely set and drive a nail into soft wood with controlled hammer strikes?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You used a real hammer and nails like a super builder today! Now, let's put our tools away safely and think about all the amazing things you might build when you grow up!

parent_notes: Woodworking is an authentic Montessori practical life activity that builds tremendous confidence. Children are capable of using real tools with proper instruction and supervision. Large-headed roofing nails are safest because the child is less likely to miss. Soft wood (balsa, pine, or thick cork) requires less force. Always clamp the wood to a stable surface — the child needs both hands free. Safety goggles are non-negotiable. Start with just hammering nails straight in; later lessons will add sanding, drilling, and simple construction. The concentration and hand-eye coordination required rival any fine motor exercise. Many children find the rhythmic hammering deeply satisfying. This work gives real competence with real tools — a core Montessori principle.

title: Grammar — The Article (Montessori Grammar Symbols)
description: Introduction to the Montessori grammar symbol for the article. The child learns that 'the,' 'a,' and 'an' are special small words called articles that come before nouns, represented by a small light blue triangle.
instructions:
1. 'You know the puzzle words the and a. Today we learn what kind of words they are!'
2. 'Words like the, a, and an are called ARTICLES. They come before a naming word.'
3. Show the Montessori grammar symbol: small light blue triangle.
4. 'The article is a tiny triangle because it is a small but important word that points to the noun.'
5. Read sentences on strips. Find the articles. Place the light blue triangle above each one.
6. 'The cat sat. A dog ran. An egg fell.' Child places triangles above the, a, an.
7. Child writes or builds sentences and marks articles with the symbol.
materials_needed: Montessori grammar symbols (light blue triangle for article)

slides.heading: Grammar
slides.subheading: The Article — Small Light Blue Triangle
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this slide! It says "Grammar" and "The Article." We are going to learn about special little words called articles and a pretty blue triangle symbol.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare sentence strips with clear articles. Have multiple small light blue triangles ready (cut from paper or use Montessori grammar symbols).
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we get to use! We have a little blue triangle that looks like a tiny mountain, some long strips of paper with words, and paper to draw or write on. We will also use a pencil and maybe some paper to make our own words!

slides.text: 'You know the words THE, A, and AN. These tiny words have a special name — they are called ARTICLES. An article comes before a thing word.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You already know some super important words like "the" and "a." Today we're going to learn that these little words are called "articles," and they like to come right before words that name something, like "dog" or "ball."

slides.text: 'In Montessori, every type of word has a symbol. The article's symbol is a small LIGHT BLUE TRIANGLE.' Show the symbol. 'It is small because articles are small words!'
slides.mascot_explanation: In our special word game, we use shapes to stand for words. The little blue triangle is our special symbol just for articles! It's small, just like the words "the," "a," and "an" are small words.

slides.text: Read a sentence strip: 'THE cat sat on A mat.' 'Find the articles! THE is an article. A is an article.' Place light blue triangles above each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at this sentence: "THE cat sat on A mat." Can you find the little words "the" and "a"? Great job! Now, let's put a blue triangle right on top of each one, like a little hat.

slides.text: 'AN is also an article. We use AN before words that start with a vowel sound: AN apple, AN egg, AN orange.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes we use the word "an" instead of "a." We use "an" when the next word starts with a yummy vowel sound, like in "AN apple" or "AN egg." It's like a special friend for those words!

slides.prompt: Read each sentence strip. Find every article (the, a, an). Place the light blue triangle symbol above it. How many articles can you find?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a word detective! We'll read some sentences, and your job is to find all the "the," "a," and "an" words and put a blue triangle above each one. How many can you find?

slides.text: 'Articles are small words with a big job — they introduce the noun! THE dog, A tree, AN island. You will see them everywhere now.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify articles in sentences and place the correct grammar symbol above them?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job finding all the articles today! Remember, those little words like "the," "a," and "an" are like little helpers that tell us about other words. You're going to see them everywhere now!

parent_notes: Montessori grammar uses visual symbols to make parts of speech concrete and memorable. Each part of speech has a unique shape and color. The article is a small light blue triangle — small because it is a minor word, triangular because in Montessori tradition all noun family words (noun, article, adjective) are triangles. The child is not expected to memorize grammar rules — they learn through physical manipulation (placing symbols) and pattern recognition. Articles are taught before adjectives because the child already knows 'the' and 'a' as puzzle words. This simply gives those familiar words a grammatical identity. You can cut triangles from light blue card stock or use commercial Montessori grammar symbols.

title: Stamp Game — Multiplication
description: The child uses the stamp game for multiplication, building the same number multiple times and combining. This transfers the golden bead multiplication concept to the more abstract stamp material.
instructions:
1. 'We multiplied with golden beads and bead bars. Now let us multiply with the stamp game!'
2. Problem: 213 taken 3 times.
3. 'Build 213 three times — three separate rows of stamps.'
4. Row 1: 2 hundreds, 1 ten, 3 units. Row 2: same. Row 3: same.
5. 'Now combine! Units: 3+3+3=9. Tens: 1+1+1=3. Hundreds: 2+2+2=6.'
6. Read the answer: 639.
7. Practice: 124 x 3, 231 x 2, 312 x 3. Exchange when needed.

slides.heading: Stamp Game Multiplication
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to play a fun game today called Stamp Game Multiplication! It's like putting groups of things together to see how many we have in total. We'll use special stamps to help us learn.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up stamp game on the mat. Prepare multiplication problems using 3-digit numbers times 2, 3, or 4.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we need for our game! We have some colorful stamps – red ones for big numbers, blue ones for medium numbers, and green ones for little numbers. We also need a mat to put them on, and some cards with problems to solve. Ask your grown-up to help you find these special stamps and get them ready!

slides.text: 'Multiplication means taking the same number several times. Let us do 213 taken 3 times with stamps!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our first big math adventure! We're going to learn how to count groups of things, just like when you get three yummy cookies three times! We'll use our special stamps to make a number and see how many we have when we put them all together.

slides.text: 'Build 213 in the first row: 2 red hundreds, 1 blue ten, 3 green units. Now build 213 again in a second row. And again in a third row.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's build our first number! We need to make the number 213 using our stamps. First, put down two red stamps for the hundreds, then one blue stamp for the tens, and finally three green stamps for the ones. We need to do this three times, making three separate lines of stamps just like this.

slides.text: 'Three rows of 213! Now combine. Start with units: 3 + 3 + 3 = 9 units. Tens: 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 tens. Hundreds: 2 + 2 + 2 = 6 hundreds.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We have three lines of 213 stamps. Now, let's count them all up together! We'll count all the little green ones first, then the blue ones, and then the big red ones. Adding them up will show us our special answer!

slides.text: 'The answer is 639! 213 taken 3 times equals 639.' Record it. 'What if we get more than 9 in one category? We exchange!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Hooray, we found our answer! We counted all the stamps and found out how many we have when we put all the groups together. We can even write down our answer to remember it. If we have too many little stamps, we can trade them for a bigger one, just like magic!

slides.prompt: Try 124 taken 3 times. Build three rows, combine, and exchange if needed. Then try 231 taken 2 times.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super stamp game expert! We're going to try some new problems all by ourselves. You'll build the numbers, count them up, and trade them if you need to. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You can now add, subtract, AND multiply with the stamp game! These stamps are very powerful tools.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform 3-digit multiplication using the stamp game, exchanging when necessary?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are amazing! You learned how to multiply using our special stamp game, which means you can count big groups of numbers super fast now. You used those powerful stamps like a math wizard!

parent_notes: Stamp game multiplication follows the exact same principle as golden bead multiplication: build the number on multiple trays (or rows), then combine. The transition from golden beads to stamps is a step toward abstraction — each stamp represents a quantity rather than physically embodying it. Problems that require exchange are important: 124 x 3 yields 12 units, which must be exchanged for 1 ten and 2 units. If the child finds this challenging, go back to a simpler problem (like 111 x 3 = 333, no exchange needed) and build complexity gradually. The stamp game prepares for long multiplication on paper by making the process of 'carrying' concrete.

title: Europe — Countries and Cultures Continued
description: Deepening the Europe puzzle map work. The child revisits the countries learned last week and adds new ones: Sweden, Greece, and Russia. Brief cultural facts bring each country to life.
instructions:
1. Review: 'Can you find Italy, France, Spain, United Kingdom, and Germany on the map?' Child places these pieces.
2. Introduce Sweden: 'This long country in the north is Sweden. It is very cold there in winter and has beautiful forests.'
3. Introduce Greece: 'This country at the bottom is Greece. The ancient Greeks built amazing temples and started the Olympic Games!'
4. Introduce Russia: 'This HUGE country stretches all the way to Asia! It is the biggest country in the world.'
5. Three-period lesson for the new countries.
6. Share one cultural fact per country (food, landmark, tradition).
7. Child rebuilds the map including all 8 countries.
materials_needed: Pictures of landmarks/foods from Sweden, Greece, Russia

slides.heading: Europe
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Europe" and "More Countries and Cultures." This means we're going to learn even more about the special places in Europe and the fun things people do there.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the puzzle map. Prepare picture cards showing landmarks or food from Sweden, Greece, and Russia.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our learning adventure! We have a big puzzle map of Europe, and some special pictures and flags to help us. We'll use these to learn all about the countries.

slides.text: 'Last week we learned five European countries. Can you place them? Italy... France... Spain... United Kingdom... Germany.' Child places each piece.
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember last week? We learned some countries in Europe! Can you find Italy, France, Spain, the United Kingdom, and Germany on our big puzzle map and put them in their special spots?

slides.text: 'Today three more! This is SWEDEN — way up north. Swedish people eat meatballs and celebrate a holiday with candles in their hair called St. Lucia Day!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's meet a new friend: Sweden! See this long country way up north? That's Sweden! People there eat yummy meatballs, and they have a special day where they wear crowns with candles!

slides.text: 'This is GREECE — at the bottom near the sea. The ancient Greeks created the Olympics! And they built beautiful white buildings called temples.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next up is Greece, down here by the water! The people in Greece long, long ago started the super fun Olympic Games! They also built beautiful white buildings that look like castles.

slides.text: 'And this enormous piece is RUSSIA — the biggest country in the world! Russian nesting dolls (matryoshka) have smaller dolls inside bigger ones.'
slides.mascot_explanation: And look at this HUGE piece – it's Russia! It's the biggest country anywhere in the whole world. They have special dolls called nesting dolls, where a tiny doll hides inside a bigger one, and another inside that!

slides.prompt: Place all 8 countries on the puzzle map. Match each country to its flag card. Tell me one fact about each country.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's your turn to be the super helper! Let's put all the countries we know onto our map, match each one to its flag, and tell me one cool thing about Sweden, Greece, and Russia. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You know 8 European countries now! Europe is full of different languages, foods, and traditions — all close together.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and place all 8 studied European countries and share a fact about each new country?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You know so many countries in Europe now – eight of them! Europe is like a big neighborhood with so many different foods, songs, and fun traditions all close together. Great job learning!

parent_notes: Building geography knowledge incrementally — adding a few countries each session — prevents overwhelm and builds lasting memory. Cultural facts make countries memorable: Swedish meatballs, Greek Olympics, Russian nesting dolls. These connections give the child mental hooks for remembering. If you have objects from these countries (a matryoshka doll, a Greek olive oil bottle, a Swedish Dala horse), bring them out as concrete connections. Flags add another visual element. Some children become passionate about particular countries and want to learn more — follow this interest with library books, cooking projects, or music. The Europe map has many small pieces; do not rush to learn them all. Depth over breadth is the Montessori approach.

title: Read-Aloud: Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel by Virginia Lee Burton
description: The classic story of Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne the steam shovel, who prove they can dig a cellar in one day. Themes of perseverance, teamwork, and adapting to change connect to the woodworking introduction.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is a story about a man and his steam shovel — a big machine that digs.'
2. Read aloud with energy. When Mike makes his promise: 'Do you think they can do it?'
3. As they dig: 'They are almost done! But wait — what is the problem?'
4. After the solution: 'How did Mike and Mary Anne solve their problem? What would you have done?'
5. Discuss: 'Mike and Mary Anne never gave up, even when things looked hard.'
6. Connect to tools: 'Mike used a big machine. You used a real hammer today! Tools help us build.'
materials_needed: Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel by Virginia Lee Burton

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is the cover of a super fun story we get to read together. It's about a man and his big, strong digging machine!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. This is a longer picture book — plan for about 15 minutes of reading time.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our story, we need two things. We need the book, and we need our drawing stuff so we can make pictures later. Can you ask your grown-up to get those ready for us?

slides.text: 'Mike Mulligan has a steam shovel named Mary Anne. They have worked together for years. But now everyone wants new machines. Will Mike and Mary Anne find work?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This story is about a man named Mike and his special steam shovel, Mary Anne. They used to dig together all the time, but now people want new machines. We'll see if Mike and Mary Anne can find a new job!

slides.text: Read aloud. At the challenge: 'Mike says he can dig the cellar in ONE DAY! Do you believe him? That is a big promise.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, Mike made a big promise! He said he can dig a whole big hole in just one day! Wow! Do you think they can really do it?

slides.text: After the problem is revealed (they are stuck): 'Oh no! They dug so well that now they cannot get out! What would YOU do?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh no! They dug so fast and so well that now Mary Anne is stuck! How do you think they are going to get out of that big hole? What would you do if you were stuck?

slides.prompt: Draw Mike and Mary Anne digging. Or design your own machine — what would it build? Draw it and tell me about it.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to use our imaginations! Let's draw a picture of Mike and Mary Anne digging, or maybe you can invent your own special machine to build things! What would your machine do?

slides.text: 'Mike never gave up, and he found a creative solution. When you work hard and think creatively, you can solve big problems too!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the story's problem and solution and connect the theme of perseverance to their own experiences?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, Mike and Mary Anne never gave up! They worked hard and thought of a clever idea to solve their problem. Just like them, when we keep trying and think hard, we can solve problems too! You did such a great job listening!

parent_notes: Virginia Lee Burton's classic pairs wonderfully with the woodworking introduction. Both involve real tools doing real work. The story has multiple layers: perseverance, the passage of time (old vs. new technology), creative problem-solving, and the value of loyal partnership. The ending — Mary Anne becoming the furnace of the building she helped create — can be read as either happy or bittersweet, and children often have interesting reactions. The illustrations show the passage of time beautifully, with the town growing around Mike and Mary Anne. This is a book many children want to hear multiple times. Burton's other books (The Little House, Katy and the Big Snow) make excellent follow-ups.

title: Geometric Solids — Bases and Faces Continued
description: Building on the geometric solids introduction, the child explores the properties of each solid more deeply: counting faces, edges, and vertices, and matching solids to their base shapes.
instructions:
1. Review the 5 geometric solids by name.
2. 'Today we look more closely at each solid. Let us count FACES.' Start with the cube.
3. Place the cube on paper. Trace one face. 'What shape is this face? A square! How many square faces does a cube have?' Count: 6.
4. Cylinder: trace the circular base. 'Two circles and one curved surface that is not a face.'
5. Cone: trace the base. 'One circle and a point at the top — that point is called an APEX.'
6. Pyramid: trace the base (square). Count the triangular faces: 4 sides + 1 base = 5 faces.
7. Match each solid to its base shape traced on paper.
materials_needed: Geometric solids (sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, pyramid)

slides.heading: Geometric Solids
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this big word: "Geometric Solids"! That just means shapes like balls and boxes and cones. Today, we're going to be super detectives and look really closely at all their special parts!

slides.setup_instructions: Place all solids on the mat. Have paper and pencil ready for tracing bases.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these fun things we get to play with! We have our cool shapes, some paper to draw on, a pencil to trace with, and special name tags. Let's get our mat ready and put all the shapes on it, then we'll be ready to be shape detectives!

slides.text: 'Name each solid as I hold it up.' Review: sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, pyramid. 'Today we become shape detectives — we will discover what each solid is made of!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's say the names of our shapes together: sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, and pyramid! You know them all! Now, we're going to be super shape detectives and find out all their secrets, like what their sides are made of.

slides.text: 'A FACE is a flat surface. Can you find a face on the cube? Put the cube on the paper and trace around it. What shape is the face? A SQUARE!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this flat part on the cube? That's called a "face"! Let's put the cube on the paper and trace around that flat part. What shape did we make? A square! You found a square face!

slides.text: 'How many faces does the cube have? Let us count by touching each one.' Count together: 6 faces. 'Where two faces meet is an EDGE. Count the edges: 12!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's count how many square faces our cube has. We touch each flat side and count: one, two, three, four, five, six! The cube has six square faces! And see where two faces meet? That's an edge, and our cube has lots of edges too!

slides.text: 'Does the sphere have faces? No! It is all curved. Does the cylinder? Two flat circle faces on the ends. And the cone has one circle face and an APEX — a point at the top.'
slides.mascot_explanation: The round ball shape, the sphere, doesn't have any flat faces, it's all smooth and curved. The cylinder has two flat circle faces, one on each end. The cone has one flat circle face and a pointy top called an apex.

slides.prompt: Trace the base of each solid on paper. Label each tracing with the solid's name. Count and record: how many faces does each solid have?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the shape detective! Let's trace the flat bottom of each shape onto the paper. Then, we'll write the name of the shape next to its tracing and count how many faces each one has. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Every solid has special properties: faces, edges, and vertices. You are becoming a geometry expert!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace the base shape of each solid and count its faces correctly?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job being a shape detective today! You learned that shapes have special parts called faces, edges, and vertices. You were so good at tracing and counting all the faces on our shapes! You're a super geometry expert now!

parent_notes: This lesson deepens geometric understanding by introducing mathematical vocabulary: face (flat surface), edge (where two faces meet), and vertex (corner point, plural: vertices; apex for the top of a cone or pyramid). Tracing the base of each solid connects 3D shapes to 2D shapes — the child sees that a cube has square faces, a cylinder has circular faces, and a pyramid has a square base with triangular sides. This is foundational for understanding surface area and nets in later math. The sphere is unique because it has no faces, edges, or vertices — it is entirely curved. Let the child discover this by trying to find a flat spot to trace. If they cannot, ask, 'Why not?'

title: Grammar — The Adjective (Montessori Grammar Symbols)
description: Introduction to the adjective and its Montessori grammar symbol: a medium dark blue triangle. The child discovers that adjectives are words that describe nouns — they tell us what kind, what color, or how many.
instructions:
1. Place an object on the table: 'Bring me a ball.' Child brings it.
2. Place two balls (different colors): 'Bring me a ball.' Which one? 'I need to say MORE! Bring me the RED ball.'
3. 'RED describes the ball. It tells us WHICH ball. Words that describe nouns are called ADJECTIVES.'
4. Present the grammar symbol: medium dark blue triangle.
5. Practice: 'The big cat. The small cat. The fluffy cat.' What word is the adjective?
6. Sentence strips: child places the dark blue triangle above each adjective.
7. Play the adjective game: add adjectives to plain nouns.
materials_needed: Montessori grammar symbols (dark blue triangle for adjective, light blue triangle for article, black triangle for noun)
Two similar objects in different colors/sizes

slides.heading: Grammar
slides.subheading: The Adjective — Medium Dark Blue Triangle
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! Today we are going to learn about special words called adjectives. They are like magic words that help us describe things! We even have a special triangle shape to help us remember them.

items: Grammar symbols: dark blue triangle (adjective), light blue triangle (article), black triangle (noun)
slides.setup_instructions: Place two similar objects that differ in one quality (color, size) on the table. Have grammar symbols and sentence strips ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these fun things we get to use today! We have colorful balls to help us practice, and special triangle shapes that stand for different kinds of words. We also have paper strips where we will write our sentences. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get everything ready!

slides.text: 'Bring me a ball.' Child brings one. 'But I wanted the other one! How do I tell you which one? I say: bring me the RED ball. RED is the word that tells you WHICH ball.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine I say, "Bring me a ball!" You might bring me any ball, right? But what if I really want the red one? I have to say, "Bring me the RED ball!" See? The word "RED" tells me exactly which ball I want.

slides.text: 'Words that DESCRIBE nouns are called ADJECTIVES. Red, big, small, soft, three, old — these are all adjectives. They tell us more about the noun.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, words like "red" or "big" or "soft" are called adjectives! They are super helpful because they tell us more about the things we are talking about, like what color something is or how it feels. Adjectives make our words more interesting!

slides.text: 'The adjective's symbol is a MEDIUM DARK BLUE TRIANGLE.' Show the symbol. 'It is bigger than the article triangle because adjectives are important describing words.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the special triangle for our adjective words! It's a medium dark blue color. Remember, this triangle helps us know when we see a word that describes something else. It's like a secret code for adjectives!

slides.text: Sentence strip: 'The fluffy cat sat on a soft mat.' 'Find the adjectives — which words describe a noun?' Child places dark blue triangles above 'fluffy' and 'soft.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at this sentence: "The fluffy cat sat on a soft mat." Can you find the words that describe things? "Fluffy" tells us about the cat, and "soft" tells us about the mat! We put our blue triangle symbol above those describing words.

slides.prompt: Read each sentence strip. Place symbols above the words: light blue triangle for articles, dark blue triangle for adjectives, black triangle for nouns. Can you find them all?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a word detective! We have some new sentences, and we need to find the nouns, the articles, and the adjectives. Remember our symbols: the black triangle for nouns, the light blue for articles, and our special dark blue triangle for adjectives. Let's see if you can find them all!

slides.text: 'Adjectives make language interesting! Without them, everything would be plain: a ball, a cat, a day. With adjectives: a shiny ball, a sleepy cat, a beautiful day!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify adjectives in sentences and distinguish them from articles and nouns?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job learning about adjectives today! You found so many describing words that make our sentences much more exciting. Without adjectives, we would just have "a cat," but with them, we can have a "sleepy cat" or a "fluffy cat"! Yay!

parent_notes: The Montessori adjective lesson is brilliantly experiential. By asking for 'a ball' when two are present, the child EXPERIENCES the need for an adjective — it is not an abstract grammar rule but a practical necessity. The detective game (bring me the ___ ball) can continue throughout the day. The grammar symbol hierarchy is logical: nouns are large black triangles (the most important words — things), adjectives are medium dark blue triangles (they describe nouns, so same family but different), and articles are small light blue triangles (minor words that introduce nouns). This visual system makes grammar tangible. The child physically places symbols above words, turning grammar analysis into a hands-on activity.

title: Introduction to Fractions — Fraction Circles
description: The child is introduced to fractions using Montessori fraction circles (fraction insets). Starting with a whole circle, they discover halves, thirds, and fourths by fitting the pieces together.
instructions:
1. Present the whole fraction circle (red). 'This is ONE WHOLE circle.'
2. Present the halves (two equal pieces). 'When we cut a whole into TWO EQUAL pieces, each piece is called ONE HALF.' Write: 1/2.
3. 'Two halves make one whole.' Assemble and disassemble.
4. Present thirds: 'Three EQUAL pieces. Each is ONE THIRD.' Write: 1/3.
5. Present fourths: 'Four equal pieces. Each is ONE FOURTH or ONE QUARTER.' Write: 1/4.
6. Mix up the pieces. Child assembles each circle.
7. Compare: 'Which is bigger, one half or one fourth? Let us check!'
materials_needed: Montessori fraction circles (whole, halves, thirds, fourths)

slides.heading: Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn about special numbers called fractions today. Fractions help us talk about parts of things, like when we share a yummy cookie!

items: Fraction circles: whole, halves, thirds, fourths
slides.setup_instructions: Set out the fraction circles in their frames. Place labels nearby. Work on a clear mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these colorful circles! We have a big red one, and then some that are cut into pieces. We also have little labels to help us name the pieces, and a special mat to work on. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these fun things!

slides.text: 'This red circle is ONE WHOLE — one complete circle, nothing missing.' Place the whole on the mat. Label it: 1.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this big red circle? This is ONE WHOLE circle, like a whole pizza before we cut it! It's all by itself, nothing is missing.

slides.text: 'Now look at this: the same size circle, but cut into TWO EQUAL pieces. Each piece is called ONE HALF.' Remove one half and hold it up. 'It takes two halves to make a whole.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now look at these two pieces! They are the same size, and when we put them together, they make a whole circle just like the red one. When a whole is cut into two equal pieces, we call each one a HALF.

slides.text: 'This circle is cut into THREE equal pieces. Each one is ONE THIRD.' Show how three thirds make a whole. 'And this one is FOUR equal pieces — ONE FOURTH or ONE QUARTER.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This circle is cut into three equal pieces, and each is called a THIRD. And this one is cut into four equal pieces, and each is called a FOURTH! So we have halves, thirds, and fourths!

slides.text: 'Let us compare! Place one half next to one fourth. Which is bigger? ONE HALF is bigger! When you cut into MORE pieces, each piece gets SMALLER.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put a half piece next to a fourth piece. See how the half is bigger than the fourth? That's because when we cut a circle into *more* pieces, each piece gets smaller.

slides.prompt: Assemble each fraction circle. Then compare: put 1/2 next to 1/3 next to 1/4. Which is biggest? Which is smallest? Draw the fractions on paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to play! Can you put all the pieces back together to make their whole circles? Then, let's line up a half, a third, and a fourth to see which one is the biggest and which is the smallest. You can even draw them!

slides.text: 'A fraction is a PART of a whole. More pieces means smaller pieces! You will use fractions when cooking, sharing, and measuring.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name halves, thirds, and fourths, assemble them into wholes, and compare their sizes?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about fractions today! Remember, fractions are just parts of a whole, and when we have more pieces, they get smaller. You're going to use fractions when you share toys or yummy snacks!

parent_notes: Fractions are one of the most challenging math concepts, and Montessori's concrete approach makes them accessible to young children. The fraction circles (also called fraction insets) are color-coded and fit into frames, making them self-correcting — pieces from different fractions do not fit in the wrong frame. The key insight at this stage is that more pieces means smaller pieces: 1/4 is smaller than 1/3, which is smaller than 1/2. This is counterintuitive (4 is bigger than 2, but 1/4 is smaller than 1/2) and needs many concrete experiences to internalize. Connect fractions to real life: cutting a pizza, sharing an apple, dividing playdough. Use fraction language throughout the day: 'You ate half your sandwich!'

title: Animal Classification — Birds (External Parts)
description: A closer study of birds as a vertebrate class. The child learns the external parts of a bird (beak, wings, feathers, talons, tail) and discovers how different beaks are adapted for different foods.
instructions:
1. 'Last week we learned the five vertebrate classes. Today we zoom in on BIRDS!'
2. Present a large picture or model of a bird. Label parts: beak, wing, feather, tail, talon/foot, eye, breast.
3. 'What makes birds special? FEATHERS! They are the only animals with feathers.'
4. Show different beak shapes: 'A hawk has a curved beak for tearing meat. A hummingbird has a long thin beak for reaching into flowers. A duck has a flat beak for scooping water.'
5. 'The beak tells us what the bird EATS!'
6. Match beak pictures to food sources.
7. Child labels a bird diagram.
materials_needed: Part labels: beak, wing, feather, tail, talon, eye

slides.heading: Birds
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this slide! It says "Birds" and talks about how they look on the outside and how their mouths are special for eating. We're going to learn all about these amazing flying friends today!

slides.setup_instructions: Display a large bird image. Prepare labels for parts. Gather pictures showing 4-5 different beak types.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these fun things we need for our bird adventure! We have a picture of a bird, some little cards with words to name its parts, and some pictures of different bird mouths, called beaks. We also have a paper with a bird on it for us to draw on, and a soft feather and a special magnifying glass to look closely. Ask your grown-up to help you find these so we can get started!

slides.text: 'Birds are vertebrates with FEATHERS. Let us learn the parts of a bird!' Point to each part on the picture and name it: beak, wing, feather, tail, talons.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at our big bird picture! Birds have special things all over them, like a beak for eating, wings for flying, feathers that keep them warm, a tail to help them steer, and feet called talons. We're going to learn all the names for these parts together!

slides.text: 'Look at this feather with the magnifying glass. See the tiny barbs? Feathers keep birds warm and help them fly. No other animal has feathers!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, feel this feather! It's so soft and light. Feathers are super special because only birds have them, and they help birds fly way up high and stay cozy. Let's look really close with the magnifying glass to see all the tiny little parts of the feather.

slides.text: 'Now look at the BEAK. Different birds have different beaks for different foods!' Show pictures: eagle (curved for meat), hummingbird (long for nectar), pelican (pouch for fish), woodpecker (strong for drilling).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at the bird's mouth, the beak! See how this one is all twisty and strong? That's like an eagle's beak, and it helps them eat yummy meat. And this super long, skinny one is like a hummingbird's, perfect for sipping sweet juice from flowers!

slides.text: 'If you see a bird's beak, you can guess what it eats! A strong, curved beak eats meat. A small, pointed beak eats seeds. A flat beak scoops water.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it cool that a bird's beak can tell us what it likes to eat? If a beak is big and flat, it might scoop up water and bugs like a duck. If it's small and pointy, it might peck seeds. We can be bird detectives and guess their favorite snacks!

slides.prompt: Label the bird diagram: beak, wing, feather, tail, talon. Then match each beak picture to the food it eats: meat, nectar, fish, insects.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to be bird experts! We get to write the names of the bird parts on our paper, like beak and wings. Then, we'll be super smart and match the pictures of the beaks to the yummy foods they help the birds eat! You can do it!

slides.text: 'Birds are amazing! Their beaks are perfectly shaped for their food. Next time you see a bird, look at its beak and guess what it eats!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child label the main external parts of a bird and explain how beak shape relates to diet?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about birds today! We learned all their body parts and how their beaks are like special tools for eating different foods. Next time you see a bird outside, you can tell me all about its beak!

parent_notes: Montessori zoology explores each animal class in depth through external parts (what you can see), internal parts (skeleton, organs — in later years), and ecology (habitat, diet). Beak adaptation is a wonderful introduction to the concept of adaptation — each species is uniquely designed for its way of life. If you have access to a real feather, the magnifying glass observation is unforgettable: the child sees the intricate barbs and barbules that make a feather both strong and light. Bird watching is a natural extension: set up a simple bird feeder and observe which birds visit and what their beaks look like. Field guides for children (like those by Sibley) make great reference materials.

title: Art — Observational Drawing: A Bird
description: The child draws a bird from observation, studying shape, proportion, and detail. This connects to the science lesson on bird anatomy and develops careful looking skills.
instructions:
1. 'Today we draw a bird! Good artists look VERY carefully before they draw.'
2. Display a picture or figurine of a bird. Study it together.
3. 'What shapes do you see? The body is like an oval. The head is a circle. The beak is a triangle.'
4. Demonstrate drawing the basic shapes first: large oval for body, circle for head, triangle for beak.
5. 'Now add details: the eye, the wing shape, the tail feathers, the legs.'
6. 'Add color — what colors are on this bird?'
7. Child draws their bird, referring to the model frequently.
materials_needed: Bird picture or figurine for reference

slides.heading: Observational Drawing
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we're going to be super artists and draw a bird! We'll look very, very closely at a real bird so we can draw it just right.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the bird reference where the child can see it clearly. Set out drawing materials.
slides.mascot_explanation: To draw our beautiful bird, we need a few special things! We need a picture or a toy bird to look at, some paper to draw on, a pencil for drawing, colorful pencils for coloring, and an eraser just in case we make a little oopsie. Can you help find these with a grown-up?

slides.text: 'Artists observe carefully before drawing. Let us look at this bird for one whole minute. What do you notice about its shape? Its colors? Its details?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job looking! Artists are like detectives – they look super carefully before they make art. Let's look at our bird friend for a whole minute and see all the cool shapes and colors it has. What do you see?

slides.text: 'Every bird starts with simple shapes. The body is an OVAL.' Draw a large oval. 'The head is a CIRCLE on top.' Add a circle. 'The beak is a small TRIANGLE.'
slides.mascot_explanation: That's right, we start with simple shapes! We'll draw a big oval for the bird's body, then a circle right on top for its head, and a little triangle sticking out for its beak. See how it's coming together?

slides.text: 'Now connect the head and body with a smooth line for the neck. Add the wing — it is like a leaf shape on the side. The tail feathers extend from the back.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's connect the head and body with a soft line for its neck, and draw a pretty leaf shape on the side for its wing. We can also draw some feathery lines in the back for its tail. It's starting to look like a real bird!

slides.text: 'Details bring it to life! Add the eye (a small circle with a dot), the legs, and the feet. Look at the reference — how many toes does it have?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're adding the special little things now! Let's draw a small circle with a dot for its eye, and then some skinny lines for its legs and feet. Can you count how many toes your bird has on the picture?

slides.prompt: Draw your bird step by step. Keep looking at the reference picture. When the shape is done, add color. Take your time — there is no rush!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to make your bird come alive! Keep looking at our bird friend as you draw, and remember to add all the shapes and details we talked about. Then, you can pick your favorite colors to make your bird super special!

slides.text: Display the drawing. 'Compare your drawing to the reference. You captured the shape of a real bird! The more you practice, the more detailed your drawings will become.'
slides.mastery_check: Did the child observe the reference carefully, use basic shapes to construct the bird, and add appropriate details?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your amazing bird! You did such a wonderful job drawing it by looking carefully at the picture. You are such a talented artist, and the more you draw, the even better you'll get!

parent_notes: Observational drawing teaches children to LOOK carefully — a skill that transfers to science, reading, and everyday life. Breaking a complex subject (a bird) into simple shapes (oval, circle, triangle) makes drawing accessible and non-intimidating. The child learns that everything can be drawn if you see the shapes within it. Do not correct the child's proportions harshly — instead, redirect attention to the reference: 'Look at the bird again — how big is the head compared to the body?' This teaches self-correction. Connecting art to science (bird anatomy) shows that learning areas overlap — a core Montessori principle. Display the finished drawing alongside the labeled bird diagram from the science lesson.

title: Woodworking — Sanding Wood
description: The child learns to sand wood smooth using sandpaper of different grits. This develops the tactile sense, hand strength, and patience while introducing the concept of preparation in woodworking.
instructions:
1. 'Before we build with wood, we need to make it SMOOTH. That is called sanding.'
2. Present three grits of sandpaper: coarse, medium, fine. Let the child feel each.
3. 'We always start with ROUGH sandpaper to remove the big bumps, then use SMOOTH sandpaper to make it silky.'
4. Demonstrate: hold the wood in one hand (or clamp it). Rub sandpaper along the grain (same direction as the lines in the wood).
5. 'Always sand WITH the grain — in the same direction as the lines in the wood.'
6. Child sands with coarse, then medium, then fine. Feel the difference between each stage.
7. 'Touch it now! So smooth! We could paint or stain this wood now.'

slides.heading: Woodworking
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look! We're going to be woodworkers today and learn how to make wood super smooth and nice. It's like giving the wood a nice, soft hug!

slides.setup_instructions: Clamp the wood piece to the table. Lay sandpaper sheets in order. Place a tray underneath to catch dust. Put on dust mask.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's see what we need for our special smoothing job! We have some blocks of wood that need our help, and these special rough papers called sandpaper. We also have a clamp to hold the wood still, a mask to keep dust out of our noses, and a cloth to wipe it clean. Can you help your grown-up find all these things?

slides.text: 'Feel this piece of wood. Is it smooth or rough? It has splinters and bumps. We will sand it smooth with SANDPAPER.' Let the child feel the rough wood.
slides.mascot_explanation: Feel this piece of wood. Ooh, it feels a little bumpy, doesn't it? We're going to use our sandpaper to make all those bumps disappear, like magic!

slides.text: 'Feel these three sandpapers. This one is very ROUGH — it is called coarse. This is medium. This one is very smooth — fine. We use them in order: rough first, smooth last.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's feel these papers. This one feels really scratchy, right? That's our coarse paper for the big bumps. This one is a little less scratchy, and this last one feels super smooth, like a soft blanket! We'll use them from scratchy to smooth.

slides.text: Demonstrate sanding: 'Go WITH the grain — see the lines in the wood? Sand in the same direction. Back and forth, back and forth.' Slow, even strokes.
slides.mascot_explanation: See the lines on the wood? We need to rub the sandpaper *with* the lines, like we're petting a kitty in the right direction. Back and forth, back and forth, nice and steady.

slides.text: 'Your turn! Start with the coarse sandpaper. Sand until the big bumps are gone. Then switch to medium. Then fine. Feel the wood between each step!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to make the wood smooth! Start with the scratchy paper to get rid of the big bumps, then use the next one, and finally the super smooth one. Remember to feel the wood after each paper to see how it's changing!

slides.prompt: Sand your wood piece with all three grits. Feel the wood after each grit — notice how it gets smoother. When you finish with fine sandpaper, wipe with the damp cloth.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to do the whole thing! Use the scratchy paper, then the medium one, and finish with the super smooth paper. Feel how soft it gets each time! After you're done, we'll wipe it clean with our damp cloth.

slides.text: 'Feel how smooth it is now! You prepared this wood for building or painting. Clean up the sawdust and put your sandpaper away.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sand with the grain using three grits in correct order, and feel the progressive smoothness?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your wood now – it's so smooth and ready for anything! You did such a great job making it feel like silk. We made it perfect for building or painting!

parent_notes: Sanding develops the tactile sense (feeling the progressive smoothness is deeply satisfying), patience (it takes time and repetition), and understanding of process (coarse to fine, rough to smooth). Sand WITH the grain — this is a real woodworking principle that produces a better finish. A dust mask is recommended, especially for sensitive children. If sanding indoors, work over a tray to catch dust and wipe with a damp cloth frequently. The three-grit progression parallels the Montessori principle of graded difficulty: start rough, refine, perfect. Some children become meditative during sanding — the rhythmic motion is calming. The finished smooth wood piece can be used in a later project (a painted sign, a small shelf, a toy).

title: Grammar — The Noun (Montessori Grammar Symbols Review)
description: Formal introduction of the noun and its Montessori grammar symbol: a large black triangle. The child reviews articles and adjectives, then learns to identify nouns and mark all three parts of speech in sentences.
instructions:
1. 'We have learned articles (small light blue triangle) and adjectives (medium dark blue triangle). Today — the NOUN!'
2. 'A noun is a NAMING word. It names a person, place, or thing.'
3. Present the large black triangle. 'The noun's symbol is the BIGGEST triangle because nouns are the most important words. Everything has a name!'
4. Play the noun game: look around the room and name everything you see. Each is a noun.
5. Sentence strips: child identifies and marks articles, adjectives, AND nouns.
6. 'The big dog ran.' Place symbols: light blue (the), dark blue (big), black (dog).
7. Child marks 5-6 sentences independently.
materials_needed: Montessori grammar symbols (black triangle for noun, dark blue for adjective, light blue for article)
Objects in the room for naming

slides.heading: Grammar
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we are going to learn about a super important part of talking and reading. It's called a noun, and it has a big, strong triangle symbol!

items: Grammar symbols: black triangle (noun), dark blue (adjective), light blue (article)
slides.setup_instructions: Have all three grammar symbols available. Prepare sentence strips with article + adjective + noun patterns.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we get to use for our lesson! We have special triangles for words, some paper strips with words on them, and a mat to work on. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find them all?

slides.text: 'We know articles and adjectives. Now the BIGGEST word type: the NOUN! A noun NAMES something. Everything you can see, touch, or think of has a name — that name is a noun.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We already know about little words like "the" and describing words like "big." Today, we're learning about naming words, called nouns! Nouns are words that name people, places, or things, like a doggy or your house.

slides.text: 'The noun's symbol is a LARGE BLACK TRIANGLE — the biggest symbol because nouns are the foundation of language.' Show the symbol.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this big, black triangle? This is the special sign for a noun! It's the biggest triangle because nouns are so important – they name everything we see and know!

slides.text: 'Look around! Name things: table, chair, book, window, pencil. All nouns! People are nouns too: mama, friend, doctor. Places: park, school, home.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a game! Look around our room right now. Can you point to something and say its name? That's right, a chair is a noun, and so is a book! Even people like "mama" or "teacher" are nouns!

slides.text: Read a sentence: 'The happy girl ate a red apple.' Find the nouns (girl, apple), adjectives (happy, red), articles (the, a). Place symbols above each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's look at this sentence together: "The happy girl ate a red apple." Can you find the naming words like "girl" and "apple"? We'll put the big black triangle over those words!

slides.prompt: Read each sentence strip. Place the correct symbol above every word you can identify: light blue for articles, dark blue for adjectives, black for nouns.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a word detective! We'll read these sentences, and you get to put the right triangle symbol over each word – the light blue one for articles, the dark blue for describing words, and the big black one for the naming words. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Article, adjective, noun — these three work as a team! The article introduces, the adjective describes, and the noun NAMES. You are a grammar detective!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify and mark articles, adjectives, and nouns in simple sentences?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You learned all about articles, adjectives, and nouns, and how they work together like a team. You are such a super smart grammar detective, and you did a fantastic job finding all those naming words!

parent_notes: The noun completes the first grammar trio: article (small light blue triangle), adjective (medium dark blue triangle), noun (large black triangle). All three are triangles because they belong to the noun family. The size hierarchy reflects importance: the noun is the core word, the adjective describes it, and the article introduces it. In Montessori grammar, children learn parts of speech through physical manipulation — placing symbols, sorting words, playing games. This is far more effective than memorizing definitions. The noun game (naming everything in the room) makes the concept tangible. Children often become excited about grammar when it is presented this way — 'Everything has a name!' Verbs will come next, represented by a red circle, symbolizing the energy of action.

title: Fraction Circles — Equivalences and Combining
description: The child explores fraction equivalences by discovering that 2/4 equals 1/2, and practices combining fractions by placing pieces side by side to see how many parts make a whole.
instructions:
1. Review: 'Show me one half. Show me one third. Show me one fourth.'
2. 'Watch this: place two fourths next to one half. Are they the same size? YES!'
3. 'Two fourths equals one half. They look different but they are the SAME amount!'
4. 'How many fourths make a whole? Let us check.' Place 1, 2, 3, 4 fourths — the circle is complete.
5. 'How many thirds make a whole? Three thirds!'
6. Challenge: 'Can you make a whole using halves AND fourths together? One half plus two fourths!'
7. Record discoveries on paper with drawings.

slides.heading: Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is our special math lesson about fractions. We're going to learn how different pieces can fit together to make something whole, just like putting puzzle pieces together!

items: Fraction circles: whole, halves, thirds, fourths
slides.setup_instructions: Set out all fraction pieces outside their frames. Have paper and crayons ready for recording discoveries.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have so many fun fraction pieces to play with today! We have big circles, and then smaller pieces like half circles, third circles, and fourth circles. We'll use our work mat to put them together, and then draw our amazing discoveries with crayons!

slides.text: 'Yesterday we learned halves, thirds, and fourths. Today we discover something amazing — some fractions are EQUAL even though they look different!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned about cutting a cookie in half, or into three or four pieces? Today, we're going to see how some of those pieces, even if they look different, can be the exact same size!

slides.text: 'Place one half on the mat. Now place two fourths next to it. Look! They are the SAME SIZE! Two fourths equals one half.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put the big half circle on our mat. Now, let's take two of the smaller, fourth-sized pieces and put them right next to the half. See? They match up perfectly – two fourths are the same as one half!

slides.text: 'How many fourths make a whole? Place them one at a time: one fourth... two fourths... three fourths... four fourths — a whole circle! 4/4 = 1.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's see how many of those little fourth pieces it takes to make a whole circle. We put one down, then another, then another, and finally the fourth one! Yep, it takes four fourths to make one whole circle, just like magic!

slides.text: 'Here is a challenge: can you make a whole circle using DIFFERENT fraction pieces together? Try one half plus two fourths!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, here's a super fun challenge for us! Can we use different kinds of pieces, like a half and some fourths, to build a whole circle? Let's try putting one half piece and two fourth pieces together and see if they make a perfect circle!

slides.prompt: Explore! How many ways can you make a whole circle? Draw each way on paper. Can you make a whole with 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/4? What about 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a fraction explorer! See how many different ways you can build a whole circle using our pieces. When you find a way, draw it on your paper so we can remember all the cool combinations you found!

slides.text: 'Fractions can be equal even when they look different. And different fractions can combine to make a whole. You are discovering the secrets of fractions!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate that 2/4 = 1/2 and find multiple ways to combine fractions into a whole?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a fantastic job today exploring fractions! You discovered that two smaller pieces can be the same size as a bigger piece, and you built whole circles in so many ways. You're becoming a real fraction superstar!

parent_notes: Fraction equivalence is a concept many older students struggle with because they learned it abstractly. The Montessori approach makes it physical: the child literally sees and feels that two fourths and one half are the same size. This sensory experience creates lasting understanding. Let the child explore freely — they may discover equivalences you did not plan to teach. Combining different fractions to make a whole is early preparation for adding fractions, though we do not use that terminology yet. The child is simply putting pieces together like a puzzle. Drawing their discoveries creates a record they can refer to later and reinforces the visual understanding. Take photographs of interesting combinations.

title: Community Helpers — Builders and Construction Workers
description: Exploring the roles of builders, carpenters, and construction workers. The child learns about the tools they use and the process of building, connecting to the woodworking practical life lessons.
instructions:
1. 'Who builds our houses, schools, and roads? BUILDERS and CONSTRUCTION WORKERS!'
2. Show pictures of construction sites, carpenters, and builders at work.
3. Name the tools: hammer, saw, drill, level, tape measure, hard hat, safety vest.
4. 'A carpenter works with WOOD — like we have been doing this week!'
5. Discuss the building process: design, foundation, frame, walls, roof.
6. Role play: 'Let us build a block tower. First the plan, then the foundation (strongest blocks on bottom), then build up!'
7. 'What would you like to build someday?'
materials_needed: Pictures of construction sites and workers
Toy construction tools or real tools
Paper and pencil for drawing a plan

slides.heading: Community Helpers
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It tells us we're going to learn all about the helpers in our community who build things like our homes and schools. We call them builders and construction workers!

slides.setup_instructions: Display pictures. Lay out tools for exploration. Have building blocks ready for the construction activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the cool things we need for our building adventure today! We have pictures of big buildings, some fun toy tools to play with, and colorful blocks to build with. We'll also use paper and a pencil to draw, and maybe even a hat to wear!

slides.text: 'This week you used a hammer and sandpaper — real woodworking tools! Some people use these tools every day. They are BUILDERS and CONSTRUCTION WORKERS.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we used a hammer and sandpaper to make things with wood? Well, some special people called builders and construction workers use tools like those every single day to build amazing things for us.

slides.text: 'Look at this construction site. Workers wear HARD HATS for safety and SAFETY VESTS so they can be seen. They use many tools.' Name and discuss each tool.
slides.mascot_explanation: See all the people working on this big building? They wear special hats called hard hats to keep their heads safe, and bright vests so everyone can see them easily. They use lots of different tools to build things up high!

slides.text: 'A CARPENTER works with wood. An ELECTRICIAN connects the wires. A PLUMBER puts in the water pipes. Many workers build ONE building together!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It takes lots of different helpers to build one big house! Some workers are like carpenters and work with wood, others make sure the lights work, and some put in the water pipes. They all work together like a team!

slides.text: 'Before building, they need a PLAN — a drawing of what they will build. Let us make a plan for our block building!' Child draws a simple plan.
slides.mascot_explanation: Before they build anything, builders need a special drawing called a plan. It's like a map for their building! Let's pretend we're builders and draw a plan for a super cool tower we can make with blocks.

slides.prompt: Draw a plan for a building. Then build it with blocks! Start with a strong foundation. Follow your plan. Is it what you imagined?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to build! We'll use our block tower plan to help us. First, we make a strong bottom, and then we build up, up, up! See if your block tower looks like the picture you drew!

slides.text: 'Builders work as a team and follow a plan. They use their hands and tools to create things people need. You are learning to be a builder too!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name several types of construction workers, their tools, and explain the basic building process?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job acting like a builder today! You worked as a team, followed your plan, and used your hands to build something amazing, just like the real builders do. You're becoming a super builder yourself!

parent_notes: This lesson connects directly to the woodworking practical life work — the child has been using the same tools that professional builders use. Emphasize that building is both a physical skill and an intellectual one — it requires planning, measurement, problem-solving, and teamwork. The design-before-building exercise (drawing a plan first) introduces the concept of architectural planning and connects to math (measurement, spatial reasoning). If possible, visit a construction site (from a safe distance) or watch a time-lapse video of a building being constructed. Children are often fascinated by the transformation from empty lot to finished building. The block-building activity with a plan gives practice in executing a design.

title: Read-Aloud: The Three Little Pigs (traditional version)
description: The classic tale of the three little pigs and the big bad wolf. Themes of planning, hard work, and the value of building well connect to construction and woodworking lessons.
instructions:
1. 'This is a very old story about three pigs who each build a house. Let us see which house is the strongest!'
2. Read aloud with dramatic wolf huffing and puffing.
3. After each house falls: 'Why did this house fall down? What was it made of?'
4. When the brick house stands: 'Why did this house survive? What is the lesson?'
5. Connect to building: 'Just like real builders — the MATERIALS and EFFORT matter!'
6. 'If YOU were building a house, what would you make it from?'
7. Draw or build the three houses with different materials (straw, sticks, blocks).
materials_needed: Straw, sticks, and blocks/bricks for demonstration

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to read a super fun story called "The Three Little Pigs"! It's about some little pigs who build houses.

items: Straw, sticks, small blocks for demonstration
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Optionally gather real straw, sticks, and blocks to demonstrate the three building materials.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the cool things we need for our story and activity! We have the book, some soft straw, some twigs, and some building blocks. We also have paper and crayons for drawing!

slides.text: 'Three little pigs leave home to build their own houses. But a wolf is watching! Which pig builds the best house? Let us find out.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part tells us that three little pigs are going to build houses all by themselves, but oh no, a big wolf is watching! We need to see which pig builds the strongest house.

slides.text: Read with expression. Huff and puff dramatically! After the straw house: 'Why was straw not strong enough?' After sticks: 'Was this better? Why not good enough?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the exciting part of the story! We'll read about the wolf trying to blow down the houses. We'll huff and puff like the wolf, and then we'll talk about why the straw house fell down.

slides.text: After the brick house stands: 'THIS house did not fall! Why? Because the third pig worked HARD and used STRONG materials.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, the brick house is still standing! This pig worked really, really hard and used strong bricks, so the wolf couldn't blow it down. It shows us that working hard makes things strong!

slides.prompt: Build three small structures: one from straw or grass, one from sticks, one from blocks. Which is strongest? Test them! Then draw the three pigs and their houses.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to be builders! We're going to make our own little houses out of straw, sticks, and blocks to see which one is the strongest, just like in the story! Then, we'll draw our own pictures of the three pigs and their houses.

slides.text: 'The lesson: hard work and good planning make something that LASTS. Whether you are building a house or learning to read — doing it well matters!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why the brick house was strongest and connect the moral to their own work?
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned that when we work hard and plan carefully, like the third little pig, the things we make can be super strong and last a long time! It's like when we learn new things, doing our best really matters!

parent_notes: The Three Little Pigs is a perfect companion to the construction/woodworking theme. The story teaches about material strength, planning, and the value of hard work — all relevant to practical life. Building actual mini-structures from straw, sticks, and blocks makes the science concrete: children can test the strength of each material. This is informal materials science! There are many retellings — the traditional version teaches the clearest moral. For a fun alternative perspective, read 'The True Story of the 3 Little Pigs' by Jon Scieszka (told from the wolf's perspective) to discuss point of view. Children love the dramatic huffing and puffing — encourage them to join in.

title: Trinomial Cube — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori trinomial cube. The child assembles the 27 blocks following the painted pattern on the box, developing spatial reasoning and preparing for algebraic concepts.
instructions:
1. Present the trinomial cube box. 'This is a special puzzle with 27 blocks inside!'
2. Open the box and show the painted pattern on the lid and sides.
3. 'The pattern on the box tells us where each block goes. Let us start with the bottom layer.'
4. Remove all blocks. Sort by color groups.
5. Build the bottom layer using the painted pattern on the bottom of the box as a guide.
6. Build the middle layer on top.
7. Build the top layer. Close the lid. 'It fits perfectly!'
8. Child rebuilds independently.

slides.heading: Trinomial Cube
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this cool picture! It's showing us a special toy called the Trinomial Cube, and we're going to learn all about it!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the trinomial cube box on the mat. Ensure all 27 pieces are present inside.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have a special box here, and a nice mat to work on. The box has a puzzle inside with lots of blocks, and the mat will help us keep everything tidy while we play.

slides.text: 'This is the TRINOMIAL CUBE. It has 27 blocks that fit together perfectly. It is like a 3D puzzle!' Open the box carefully.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our Trinomial Cube! It's a super fun puzzle with 27 little blocks inside that fit together like magic. Let's open it up carefully and see what's inside!

slides.text: 'Look at the pattern painted on the box. The colors tell us where each block goes. Let us take all the blocks out and sort them by color.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See all the pretty colors painted on the box? Those colors are like clues that show us where each block needs to go. Let's take all the blocks out and sort them by their colors first.

slides.text: 'Start with the bottom layer. The big red cube goes in this corner. Next to it goes this block... Match the colors to the pattern on the box.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to build the first part, the bottom layer, using the colors on the box as our guide. We'll put the big red block in the corner, and then find the blocks that match the picture next to it.

slides.text: 'Layer by layer — bottom, middle, top. Each block has only ONE place where it fits. The colors and sizes guide you.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We keep building up, layer by layer, like building a tower! Each block has a special spot where it fits perfectly, and the colors and sizes will help us find it.

slides.prompt: Take out all the blocks and rebuild the cube! Use the painted pattern to guide you. Work layer by layer. When you finish, close the lid — does it fit?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to build the whole cube all by yourself! Use the colors on the box to help you put all the blocks in the right place, layer by layer. When you're done, try to close the lid – it should fit perfectly!

slides.text: 'You assembled 27 blocks into a perfect cube! This puzzle trains your eyes and hands to think in three dimensions.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child assemble the trinomial cube correctly using the color guide on the box?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You put all 27 blocks together to make a perfect cube! You used your eyes and hands to build something amazing, just like a super builder!

parent_notes: The trinomial cube is one of Montessori's most fascinating materials. At the primary level, it is presented as a sensorial puzzle — the child matches colors and sizes without knowing it represents the algebraic formula (a + b + c) cubed. The cube contains exactly 27 blocks: cubes and prisms in red, blue, yellow, and black. The pattern on the box serves as a control of error. The child works through spatial reasoning, visual discrimination, and fine motor precision. Do not explain the algebra — the child is preparing for it sensorially, just as they prepared for writing through the metal insets. This material is typically repeated many times, and children often develop deep concentration while building it.

title: Reading Comprehension — Answering Questions About a Story
description: The child reads a short story independently and answers simple comprehension questions: who, what, where, when. This develops the skill of reading for meaning, not just decoding words.
instructions:
1. 'You have been reading so well! Today we practice understanding WHAT we read.'
2. Present a short story (4-6 sentences, phonetic with familiar phonograms and puzzle words).
3. Child reads the story aloud. Help only when asked.
4. 'Now let us think about the story.' Ask comprehension questions:
   - 'WHO is in the story?'
   - 'WHAT happened?'
   - 'WHERE did it happen?'
5. Child answers orally. If unsure, reread the relevant sentence.
6. Introduce question cards: child draws one and finds the answer in the text.
7. Child draws a picture showing what happened in the story.

slides.heading: Reading Comprehension
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Reading Comprehension," which means we're going to be super readers today and really understand the stories we read! It's like being a detective for words!

items: Question cards: who, what, where, when
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 2-3 short stories the child can decode. Write question cards. Set up a comfortable reading spot.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our reading adventure! We have some short stories for you to read, and these cool cards that ask "who," "what," and "where." We'll also use this mat and some crayons to draw our favorite part.

slides.text: 'Reading is more than just saying the words — it is about understanding the MEANING. Today we practice thinking about what we read.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You are already such a good reader! Today, we're going to practice thinking about the stories after we read them. It's like putting together a puzzle to understand what happened.

slides.text: Present the story. 'Read this story aloud to me. Take your time and think about what is happening.' Child reads.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, here is our story! Take your time and read it out loud, nice and slow. Think about the characters and what they are doing as you read each word.

slides.text: 'Great reading! Now let me ask you some questions. WHO is in the story? WHAT did they do? WHERE were they?' Child answers orally.
slides.mascot_explanation: You read that story so well! Now, let's think about it. Can you tell me WHO was in the story? And WHAT did they do? Or WHERE did all the fun happen?

slides.text: 'If you are not sure, look back at the story and find the answer. Good readers reread to check! Point to the sentence that tells you.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, it's tricky to remember everything, and that's okay! If you're not sure about an answer, we can look back at the story together. Just point to the sentence that tells us the answer!

slides.prompt: Read the next story. Then draw a question card and answer it. Can you find the answer IN the text? Draw a picture of the story.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a fun part! We'll read another story, and then you'll pick a question card. See if you can find the answer right there in the story, and then draw a picture of your favorite part!

slides.text: 'You did not just read the words — you UNDERSTOOD them! That is what real reading is. Keep asking yourself: who, what, where, when?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child answer who, what, and where questions about a story they have read independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such an amazing reader! You didn't just read the words, you understood the whole story, like a super smart detective! Remember to always think about who, what, and where!

parent_notes: Reading comprehension is a separate skill from decoding. Many children can sound out words perfectly but struggle to remember or understand what they read, especially when they are concentrating hard on decoding.
